title: At This Point, Only 20 Champions Have No Mobility.
body:
No dashes, no movement speed boosts.

{{champion:34}} {{champion:1}} {{champion:22}} {{champion:63}} {{champion:122}} {{champion:31}}{{champion:30}} {{champion:96}} {{champion:75}} {{champion:25}} {{champion:90}} {{champion:99}} {{champion:50}} {{champion:134}} {{champion:44}} {{champion:161}} {{champion:45}} {{champion:110}} {{champion:101}} {{champion:143}}

20/140, or about 14%.

(Kog was an exception since his movement speed boost is upon his death)

-------------------------------------------------

edit; Due to popular demand, let's add champions with no dashes, but movement speed increases:

{{champion:53}} {{champion:119}} {{champion:36}} {{champion:69}} {{champion:41}} {{champion:86}} {{champion:74}} {{champion:43}} {{champion:222}} {{champion:202}} {{champion:40}} {{champion:10}} {{champion:85}} {{champion:267}} {{champion:82}} {{champion:21}} {{champion:117}} {{champion:20}} {{champion:2}} {{champion:61}} {{champion:33}} {{champion:16}} {{champion:37}} {{champion:72}} {{champion:15}} {{champion:14}} {{champion:27}} {{champion:68}} {{champion:29}} {{champion:48}} {{champion:17}} {{champion:77}} {{champion:112}} {{champion:8}} {{champion:106}} {{champion:498}} {{champion:26}} {{champion:83}}

58/140 champions in the game do not have dashes, blinks, or teleports... A total of 41.5%.

More than half the champion roster now have some sort of dash.

----------------------------------------

I feel like you could almost make a game mode with just the first champions and call it "Immobility". All-out poke / skillshot war.

Not really trying to make a point or anything, though. Was just thinking about this today at work. Mobility has been on the rise in the last few years, but I didn't realize just how much until making this list.

Do you think the amount of mobility in the game has hurt or helped it?

replies.body:
i consider not having "mobility" as no leaps/dashes/escapes. That is my definition. 
Kind of funny how you can take ghost/flash on ANY champion and they get an escape using your logic then.

Also, i feel it makes counterplay happen. People like darius/veigar are more of fighting to live, rather than escaping. They have to fight their way out or be in a good position. usually champions who have better kits for late game have no mobility. All the ones up here listed are mostly fitting that description. IF they had mobility imagine how busted they'd be :)

This is not only correct, but can actually be game-changing in certain cases. Darius's ult is counted as a dash, and causes him to move to his target while ulting: unlike "typical" damage ults, Darius's ult can therefore be interrupted or prevented with the right kind of CC, namely anything that can knock him down or ground him. Darius therefore has mobility, however small it is in practice.
Darius ult can only be interrupted when he loses vision of an enemy he is ulting, CC can't stop him from ulting.
roots and grounded can prevent him from ulting though.

> [{quoted}](name=Teridax68,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=pmpsQFE7,comment-id=00010000,timestamp=2018-03-14T01:31:19.378+0000)
>
> This is not only correct, but can actually be game-changing in certain cases. Darius's ult is counted as a dash, and causes him to move to his target while ulting: unlike "typical" damage ults, Darius's ult can therefore be interrupted or prevented with the right kind of CC, namely anything that can knock him down or ground him. Darius therefore has mobility, however small it is in practice.

So in theory {{champion:78}} could counter Darius ult? And {{champion:69}} can prevent him from ulting to begin with?
I can confirm the Cass interaction (Singed as well), but I don't think Poppy W works

You can break Darius ult with any kind of CC, it's an unstopable dash. So Poppy can't knock him down.

But, it's still a dash, so root or grounded can prevent him from casting it in the first place.

It's exactly the same way as Malphite's ult works, only the range is shorter.
Well Garen's Q is a micro-dash as well.

I think mobility, like most other mechanics, can be healthy and fun when applied in proper context. However, the problem with mobility in League is that it has become practically mandatory to kits, and as a result has become limiting. When a feature is repeated so often in kits, it feels like that feature is more of a limitation, and when too many of these mandatory mechanics pile up, the results often end up feeling like the same collection of features rearranged in slightly different combinations. Percent health damage is another example of this, and has been present on almost every new or reworked kit in recent times.

Mobility specifically, though, has caused a great deal many problems of its own: the first is that, when it offers players a way of quickly closing the distance to reach an opponent, it effectively renders battlefields smaller by comparison, since much of an area can be bypassed. League's map hasn't really evolved with this, which has combined with recent damage increases to create a Call of Duty-like atmosphere, where an opponent on the edge of your screen can catch up to you in a couple of seconds and kill you without giving all that much of a reaction time. Additionally, when these dashes are offensive in nature, they also tend to render games more snowbally, since those dashes become super good when you have an edge on an enemy (you get to kill them more), but useless if you're behind (dashing means offering yourself up to get killed). Because most dashes bypass terrain, this also tends to trivialize terrain from both the map and champion kits, and again causes the map to age poorly. This is likely why Riot has experimented much more recently with giving champions dashes that don't cross over terrain, namely with Ornn, Urgot and Galio.

Overall, one of the problems with mobility in League is that Riot has always had some trouble estimating its power. Originally they completely underestimated the strength of dashes, which led to waves of mobile champions becoming OP, but even now it's not always clear if mobility is being used with a specific purpose, other than to make a champion more fun to play: the problem with giving a champion "fun" mechanics purely for the sake of fun is that, if those mechanics don't relate to their theme or kit, the champion ends up becoming shallower and less consistent. If the champion ends up being designed around the mechanic , and if that mechanic is too present, kits end up feeling too similar, a problem that exists with several classes (divers and assassins have a lot of overlap, for example). Moreover, designing champions around "fun" mechanics purely because those mechanics are popular, as is the case with dashes, ends up falling into a trap, since while those champions can generate short-term interest, in the long term they lose value if not counterbalanced with alternatives. As a result, because Riot has tried so hard to capitalize on mobility due to its popularity, League has ended up losing a fair bit of diversity, since having mobility is no longer something special.

Because of this, I think the solution should be to desaturate League of its excessively repeated mechanics, which among many others includes mobility. In many cases, certain champions either have mobility when they shouldn't, or simply have too much mobility. However, the fact that the near-totality of melee champions have some form of movement enhancement to me suggests that mobility is also somewhat of a necessity: Gangplank, for example, has a 30% movespeed bonus that is practically always-on in fights, because that's how much he needs to be able to move around properly. By contrast, Nasus, despite all of his terrifying power at melee range, and tremendous durability, suffers in many teamfights, because his total lack of mobility tools means he can get kited ad infinitum. It might therefore be the case that melee champions are given mobility out of necessity, and not just as a fun addition, which is one reason why their kits come across as overloaded. In this respect, buffing the base movespeed of melee champions, and removing some of their extraneous mobility could therefore allow melee kits to be designed without always having to resort to gapclosers or hastes.

> [{quoted}](name=Teridax68,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=pmpsQFE7,comment-id=000d,timestamp=2018-03-14T04:03:36.886+0000)
>

>

Originally they completely underestimated the strength of dashes, which led to waves of mobile champions becoming OP, but even now it's now always clear if mobility is being used with a specific purpose, other than to make a champion more fun to play: the problem with giving a champion "fun" mechanics purely for the sake of fun is that, if those mechanics don't relate to their theme or kit, the champion ends up becoming shallower and less consistent. If the champion ends up being designed around the mechanic, if that mechanic is too present, kits end up feeling too similar, a problem that exists with several classes (divers and assassins have a lot of overlap, for example). Moreover, designing champions around "fun" mechanics purely because those mechanics are popular, as is the case with dashes, ends up falling into a trap, since while those champions can generate short-term interest, in the long term they lose value if not counterbalanced with alternatives. As a result, because Riot has tried so hard to capitalize on mobility due to its popularity, League has ended up losing a fair bit of diversity, since having mobility is no longer something special.

In this respect, buffing the base movespeed of melee champions, and removing some of their extraneous mobility could therefore allow melee kits to be designed without always having to resort to gapclosers or hastes.

Bravo. You've said my thoughts way more eloquently than I ever could.
Can you really count a movement speed boost as mobility while in combat though? Generally all it takes is one slow to negate it and nearly everyone has a slow.

{{champion:12}} {{champion:32}} {{champion:201}} {{champion:131}} {{champion:60}} {{champion:420}} {{champion:39}} {{champion:427}} {{champion:145}} {{champion:89}} {{champion:57}} {{champion:80}} {{champion:133}} {{champion:107}} {{champion:412}} {{champion:62}} {{champion:5}} {{champion:157}} relies on other champions/minions/monsters to be mobile. I don't think they have true mobility. {{champion:136}} {{champion:9}} {{champion:13}} {{champion:223}} {{champion:163}} {{champion:4}} {{champion:142}} aren't mobile. Having a dash/blink doesn't make champion instantly mobile. Champions like {{champion:43}} {{champion:85}} {{champion:15}} are more mobile than most of these champions while having no dash/blink.
{{champion:9}} has mobility?

Morde's W gives him movement speed when walking towards a target with the other part of his W
FIddlesticks has a passive that gives him movement speed

> [{quoted}](name=invisiblecat1,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=pmpsQFE7,comment-id=00090000,timestamp=2018-03-14T03:20:01.361+0000)
>
> Morde's W gives him movement speed when walking towards a target with the other part of his W
> FIddlesticks has a passive that gives him movement speed

Fiddlesticks requires him to stand still first. I'm not sure if I'd call that 'mobility'.
He also has a blink on his ult, y'know. . .
Which he has to root himself first to use, and is, yknow, his ult.

He's cosidering {{champion:120}} to be immobile and {{champion:9}} to be mobile.
{{sticker:sg-syndra}}
Fid has a blink too.

His "blink" is a **high cd** ultimate that **he's almost useless without** (which means he can't waste it just for mobility).
On fiddle it's always better to die than to try to escape with his ulti (and then risk not having it later).

> [{quoted}](name=Lakrosin,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=pmpsQFE7,comment-id=0009,timestamp=2018-03-14T03:12:25.786+0000)
>
> {{champion:9}} has mobility?

Movement speed passive and blink ult.

This can be argued. The passive works psychologically to take advantage of a situation but not helpful to run away, make instant plays or chase. The ult is a tactical damage AOE that blinks him but only after channeling. It is technically mobility but taken it into account with the nature of the game it's not really mobile advantage but more like a situational one. So Fiddle has to enter a stage where he can achieve mobility doesn't really have it from the get go like kog maw when he dies.
{{champion:72}} ..
Skarner most definitely has a speed boost.
Illaoi should be included. Her "leap" is more of a hop and gives her no mobility whatsoever. Just extends her AA range slightly if anything.

Yet {{champion:34}} {{champion:1}} {{champion:63}} {{champion:122}} {{champion:31}} {{champion:75}} {{champion:25}} {{champion:90}} {{champion:99}} {{champion:50}} {{champion:134}} {{champion:44}} {{champion:161}} {{champion:45}} {{champion:110}} {{champion:101}} {{champion:143}} are still completly viable and prove mobility creep is not needed on every champion. I do think there has been mobility creep for some time, but there really isn't any way for riot to fix this. The champions are already out and if they make a none mobile champion they would have to be really strong in some aspects of their kit rather it be tons of cc tons of dmg or super tanky.
So {{champion:62}} is "mobile" just because he has an enemy reliant point click dash that can't be used in any other way or freely to escape. yeah, you're right, Wukong is a mobile champion.
You play Ashe and get dived in a team fight, he feels really mobile.

I consider no mobility as the following -

1. No leaps
2. No dashes.
3. No on demand movement speed increases like Draven W, Sona E.


Mobility from items such as protobelt is not counted.



I'd consider these champions as "immobile" -  (Some may be missing)

{{champion:22}} {{champion:1}} {{champion:34}} {{champion:53}} {{champion:63}} {{champion:122}} {{champion:9}} {{champion:74}} {{champion:420}} {{champion:222}} {{champion:30}} {{champion:96}} {{champion:99}} {{champion:54}} {{champion:90}} {{champion:25}} {{champion:267}} {{champion:75}} {{champion:111}} {{champion:134}} {{champion:110}} {{champion:161}} {{champion:45}} {{champion:112}} {{champion:101}} {{champion:427}} {{champion:16}} {{champion:44}} 



If the champion has an easy to activate movement speed steroid in their kit then I don't consider them mobile but I also don't consider them immobile, more in the middle.

Champions like {{champion:119}} {{champion:202}} {{champion:498}} {{champion:77}} {{champion:48}} {{champion:37}}  come to mind.

{{champion:42}} Passive slow is nuts.
Where is {{champion:82}} in the first list

I knew coming into this I wouldn't see {{champion:4}}  on the list. A semi-global teleport that has a 1.5 second delay and is down for over 70 seconds at BEST is being considered mobility on the same tier as {{champion:7}}  If you would genuinely consider TF a mobile champion then I'd hate to see the stone walls you consider immobile.

> let's add champions with no dashes, but movement speed increases:

I would very much hesitate to call Zilean, Singed, or Rammus immobile
mobility is cancer

"No movement speed boost" 
{{champion:122}}  LUL

You forgot his passive I think.

> [{quoted}](name=saltran,realm=EUW,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=pmpsQFE7,comment-id=0014,timestamp=2018-03-14T06:50:03.766+0000)
>
> "No movement speed boost" 
> {{champion:122}}  LUL
> 
> You forgot his passive I think.

I think you forgot his rework.

It just feels really bad when you're Vel'Koz and if you don't burst them down, they live, because they can dash away and you can't. Or how  the entire enemy 5 will dash into your lane and you can't run away or survive it. I feel like Veigar is okay cuz his cage. But Vel is just. So... immobile and defenseless.

There are a couple of tricks for surviving as a Vel'koz, mostly using your cc to it's fullest when escaping (since both his e AND Q are multitarget cc with decent range) and keeping the area well warded so you can retreat from larger ganks in advance. (unless they 5 man dive you under turret, there's not really much to be done at that point)

Vel'koz is actually really good at kiting most champs without an artillery-class attack range.
